articles.title: Macarca Kayƒ±nvalide ve Kayƒ±npeder ƒ∞fadeleri: Aile Tanƒ±≈ümasƒ±
articles.content:
# Macarca Kayƒ±nvalide ve Kayƒ±npeder ƒ∞fadeleri: Aile Tanƒ±≈ümasƒ±

Macar aileleri sƒ±cak ve misafirperverdir. Aile baƒülarƒ± g√º√ßl√ºd√ºr ve kayƒ±nvalide/kayƒ±npederle iyi ili≈ükiler kurmak √ßok deƒüerlidir. Bu rehberde Macarca aile ileti≈üimi i√ßin gereken ifadeleri √∂ƒüreneceksiniz.

## Temel Hitap ≈ûekilleri

### 1. "Any√≥s" / "Ap√≥s"
**Telaffuz:** "Anyo≈ü / Apo≈ü"
**Anlam:** Kayƒ±nvalide / Kayƒ±npeder

### 2. "√ñr√ºl√∂k, hogy megismerhetem"
**Telaffuz:** "√ñr√ºl√∂k, hody megismerhetem"
**Anlam:** Tanƒ±≈ütƒ±ƒüƒ±mƒ±za memnunum

## √ñnemli ƒ∞fadeler

### 3. "K√∂sz√∂n√∂m, hogy megh√≠vtak"
**Telaffuz:** "K√∂sz√∂n√∂m, hody meghivtak"
**Anlam:** Beni davet ettiƒüiniz i√ßin te≈üekk√ºrler

### 4. "Az √©tel fantasztikus volt"
**Telaffuz:** "Az etel fantastikus volt"
**Anlam:** Yemek fantastikti

### 5. "Nagyon sz√©p az otthonuk"
**Telaffuz:** "Nadyon sep az otthonuk"
**Anlam:** Eviniz √ßok g√ºzel

### 6. "Nagyon szeretem a gyermek√ºket"
**Telaffuz:** "Nadyon seretem a dyermekuket"
**Anlam:** √áocuƒüunuzu √ßok seviyorum

### 7. "Seg√≠thetek valamiben?"
**Telaffuz:** "≈ûeƒüithetek valamiben?"
**Anlam:** Bir konuda yardƒ±mcƒ± olabilir miyim?

### 8. "Mes√©ljenek a csal√°djukr√≥l"
**Telaffuz:** "Me≈üelyenek a √ßaladyukrol"
**Anlam:** Aileniz hakkƒ±nda anlatƒ±r mƒ±sƒ±nƒ±z?

### 9. "Nagyon √∂r√ºl√ºnk, hogy itt lehet√ºnk"
**Telaffuz:** "Nadyon √∂r√ºl√ºnk, hody it lehet√ºnk"
**Anlam:** Burada olmaktan √ßok mutluyuz

### 10. "K√∂sz√∂n√∂m a csod√°latos est√©t"
**Telaffuz:** "K√∂sz√∂n√∂m a √ßodalato≈ü estet"
**Anlam:** Harika bir ak≈üam i√ßin te≈üekk√ºrler

### 11. "Alig v√°rom, hogy jobban megismerjem √∂n√∂ket"
**Telaffuz:** "Ali varom, hody yobban megismeryem √∂n√∂ket"
**Anlam:** Sizi daha iyi tanƒ±mayƒ± sabƒ±rsƒ±zlƒ±kla bekliyorum

## K√ºlt√ºrel ƒ∞pu√ßlarƒ±

**√ái√ßek ve Hediye:** ƒ∞lk ziyarette √ßi√ßek veya bonbon (√ßikolata) getirmek √ßok takdir edilir.

**Resmi Hitap:** ƒ∞lk ba≈üta "√∂n" (siz) kullanƒ±n. Aile sizi "te" (sen) kullanmaya davet edebilir.

**Yemek K√ºlt√ºr√º:** Macar yemekleri lezzetli ve bolca ikram edilir. Her ≈üeyi tatmak ve beƒüeninizi ifade etmek √∂nemlidir.

**P√°linka:** Macar meyve rakƒ±sƒ± olan p√°linka sƒ±klƒ±kla ikram edilir. Reddetmek kaba sayƒ±labilir, en azƒ±ndan bir yudum i√ßin te≈üekk√ºr edin.

**Ayakkabƒ± √áƒ±karma:** √áoƒüu Macar evinde ayakkabƒ± √ßƒ±karƒ±lƒ±r ve terlik giyilir.

**T√ºrk-Macar Baƒülarƒ±:** ƒ∞ki k√ºlt√ºr arasƒ±ndaki tarihi baƒülarƒ± bilmek ve bahsetmek ilgi √ßekici bir sohbet konusu olabilir.

## Sonu√ß

Macar kayƒ±nvalide ve kayƒ±npederinizle iyi ili≈ükiler kurmak, sƒ±caklƒ±k ve saygƒ± gerektirir. Macar misafirperverliƒüinin tadƒ±nƒ± √ßƒ±karƒ±n ve aile baƒülarƒ±nƒ± g√º√ßlendirin!

articles.title: Frases de Apoyo Emocional en Checo: C√≥mo Consolar a Tu Pareja
articles.content:
El checo permite expresar apoyo emocional con profundidad y sinceridad. Estas frases te ayudar√°n a consolar a tu pareja checa.

## Frases de Consuelo B√°sicas

### "Jsem tu pro tebe"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** ysem tu pro t√©be

**Significado:** Estoy aqu√≠ para ti

### "V≈°echno bude v po≈ô√°dku"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** vsh√©jno b√∫de v porz√°dku

**Significado:** Todo estar√° bien

### "Je mi moc l√≠to, ≈æe t√≠m proch√°z√≠≈°"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** ye mi mots l√≠to, zhe t√≠m proj√°zish

**Significado:** Siento mucho que est√©s pasando por esto

## Ofreciendo Apoyo

### "Co pr√°vƒõ teƒè pot≈ôebuje≈°?"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** tso pr√°vie ted potrseb√∫yesh

**Significado:** ¬øQu√© necesitas ahora mismo?

### "Udƒõl√°m v≈°echno, co m≈Ø≈æu, abych ti pomohl/a"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** udiel√°m vsh√©jno, tso m√∫zhu, abij ti pom√≥jl/a

**Significado:** Har√© todo lo que pueda para ayudarte

### "Chce≈° o tom mluvit?"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** jtsesh o tom ml√∫vit

**Significado:** ¬øQuieres hablar de ello?

### "Poslouch√°m tƒõ"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** poslovh√°m tie

**Significado:** Te escucho

## Validando Emociones

### "Je norm√°ln√≠ c√≠tit se takhle"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** ye norm√°lni ts√≠tit se t√°hle

**Significado:** Es normal sentirse as√≠

### "Tv√© pocity jsou zcela pochopiteln√©"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** tv√© potsiti s√≥u ztsela pojopit√©lne

**Significado:** Tus sentimientos son completamente comprensibles

## Frases de √Ånimo

### "Jsi silnƒõj≈°√≠, ne≈æ si mysl√≠≈°"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** ysi silni√©yshi, nesh si m√≠slish

**Significado:** Eres m√°s fuerte de lo que piensas

### "Vƒõ≈ô√≠m v tebe"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** vi√©rzim v t√©be

**Significado:** Creo en ti

### "Zvl√°dneme to spolu"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** zl√°dneme to sp√≥lu

**Significado:** Lo superaremos juntos

## Expresando Amor

### "Miluji tƒõ, a≈• se stane cokoliv"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** m√≠l√∫yi tie, at se st√°ne tsokoliv

**Significado:** Te amo, pase lo que pase

### "Nejsi v tom s√°m/sama"
**Pronunciaci√≥n:** n√©ysi v tom s√°m/s√°ma

**Significado:** No est√°s solo/a en esto

El apoyo emocional checo combina profundidad con sinceridad. ¬°Dr≈æ se!

articles.title: Portugiesische Vergangenheit: Pret√©rito vs. Imperfeito
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

# Portugiesische Vergangenheit: Pret√©rito Perfeito vs. Imperfeito

Die Unterscheidung zwischen diesen beiden Zeiten ist f√ºr deutsche Lerner oft verwirrend, da wir im Deutschen haupts√§chlich das Perfekt und Pr√§teritum nach anderen Regeln verwenden.

## Der grundlegende Unterschied

<PhraseOfDay
  verb="Pret√©rito Perfeito vs. Imperfeito"
  meaning="Abgeschlossene Handlung vs. Andauernde/wiederholte Handlung"
  pronunciation="Pre-teh-ree-too per-fey-too / Im-per-fey-too"
  context="Die wichtigste Unterscheidung in der portugiesischen Vergangenheit"
/>

**Pret√©rito Perfeito**: Einmalige, abgeschlossene Handlung in der Vergangenheit
**Imperfeito**: Andauernde, gewohnheitsm√§√üige oder beschreibende Handlung

## Pret√©rito Perfeito (Abgeschlossene Vergangenheit)

<ConjugationTable
  verb="falar (Pret√©rito Perfeito)"
  meaning="sprach / habe gesprochen"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "eu", word: "falei" },
    { person: "tu", word: "falaste" },
    { person: "ele/ela/voc√™", word: "falou" },
    { person: "n√≥s", word: "fal√°mos/falamos" },
    { person: "v√≥s", word: "falastes" },
    { person: "eles/voc√™s", word: "falaram" }
  ]}
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="Eu falei com ela ontem"
  meaning="Ich habe gestern mit ihr gesprochen"
  pronunciation="Eh-oo fa-ley kong eh-la on-teng"
  example="Eu falei com ela ontem sobre nossos planos."
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="N√≥s nos conhecemos em 2020"
  meaning="Wir haben uns 2020 kennengelernt"
  pronunciation="Nosh noosh ko-nye-seh-moosh eng dois mil e vinte"
  example="N√≥s nos conhecemos em 2020 numa festa."
/>

## Imperfeito (Beschreibende Vergangenheit)

<ConjugationTable
  verb="falar (Imperfeito)"
  meaning="sprach (gew√∂hnlich) / pflegte zu sprechen"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "eu", word: "falava" },
    { person: "tu", word: "falavas" },
    { person: "ele/ela/voc√™", word: "falava" },
    { person: "n√≥s", word: "fal√°vamos" },
    { person: "v√≥s", word: "fal√°veis" },
    { person: "eles/voc√™s", word: "falavam" }
  ]}
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="Quando eu era crian√ßa, falava alem√£o em casa"
  meaning="Als ich Kind war, sprach ich zu Hause Deutsch"
  pronunciation="Kwan-doo eh-oo eh-ra kree-an-sa, fa-la-va a-le-m√£w eng ka-za"
  example="Quando eu era crian√ßa, sempre falava alem√£o com meus av√≥s."
/>

<CultureTip
  title="Eselsbr√ºcke"
  flag="üá©üá™"
>
  Stellen Sie sich das Imperfeito wie eine Filmszene vor, die im Hintergrund abl√§uft. Das Pret√©rito Perfeito ist wie ein Foto - ein einzelner, eingefrorener Moment. "Eu estava lendo" (Ich las gerade) vs. "Eu li" (Ich las/habe gelesen).
</CultureTip>

## Wann welche Zeit verwenden?

### Pret√©rito Perfeito verwenden f√ºr:

<VocabCard
  verb="Eu vi um filme ontem"
  meaning="Ich habe gestern einen Film gesehen"
  pronunciation="Eh-oo vee ung feel-mee on-teng"
  example="Einmalige, abgeschlossene Handlung"
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="Ela nasceu em Lisboa"
  meaning="Sie wurde in Lissabon geboren"
  pronunciation="Eh-la na-seh-oo eng Lish-bo-a"
  example="Einmaliges Ereignis in der Vergangenheit"
/>

### Imperfeito verwenden f√ºr:

<VocabCard
  verb="Quando √©ramos jovens, viaj√°vamos muito"
  meaning="Als wir jung waren, reisten wir viel"
  pronunciation="Kwan-doo eh-ra-moosh scho-vensh, vee-a-scha-va-moosh mooy-too"
  example="Gewohnheitsm√§√üige Handlung in der Vergangenheit"
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="O sol brilhava e os p√°ssaros cantavam"
  meaning="Die Sonne schien und die V√∂gel sangen"
  pronunciation="Oo sol bree-lya-va ee oosh pa-sa-roosh kan-ta-vang"
  example="Beschreibung von Hintergrund/Zust√§nden"
/>

## Die beiden Zeiten zusammen

<VocabCard
  verb="Eu estava dormindo quando voc√™ ligou"
  meaning="Ich schlief (gerade), als du angerufen hast"
  pronunciation="Eh-oo esh-ta-va dor-min-doo kwan-doo vo-seh lee-goh"
  example="Imperfeito f√ºr den Hintergrund, Perfeito f√ºr die Unterbrechung"
/>

<VocabCard
  verb="Ela lia um livro quando eu cheguei"
  meaning="Sie las ein Buch, als ich ankam"
  pronunciation="Eh-la lee-a ung lee-vroo kwan-doo eh-oo she-gey"
  example="Zwei verschiedene Zeiten in einem Satz"
/>

## Verben "ser" und "estar" im Imperfeito

<ConjugationTable
  verb="ser (Imperfeito)"
  meaning="war (beschreibend)"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "eu", word: "era" },
    { person: "tu", word: "eras" },
    { person: "ele/ela/voc√™", word: "era" },
    { person: "n√≥s", word: "√©ramos" },
    { person: "eles/voc√™s", word: "eram" }
  ]}
/>

<ConjugationTable
  verb="estar (Imperfeito)"
  meaning="war (vor√ºbergehend)"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "eu", word: "estava" },
    { person: "tu", word: "estavas" },
    { person: "ele/ela/voc√™", word: "estava" },
    { person: "n√≥s", word: "est√°vamos" },
    { person: "eles/voc√™s", word: "estavam" }
  ]}
/>

<CTA
  text="√úben Sie die Vergangenheitsformen mit personalisierten √úbungen"
  buttonText="Mit Love Languages lernen"
/>

articles.title: Meeting Your Turkish Partner's Family
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Meeting your Turkish partner's family is a significant milestone. In Turkish culture, family approval matters deeply, and making a good first impression can set the foundation for your future together. This guide will prepare you with the language, customs, and cultural knowledge you need to win over your partner's family.

## Your First Greeting

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Memnun oldum"
  translation="Nice to meet you / I am pleased"
  pronunciation="mem-NOON ol-DOOM"
  context="The essential phrase when meeting anyone for the first time. Said while shaking hands or after kisses on the cheek, this shows you are happy to meet them."
/>

First impressions matter enormously in Turkish culture. Here is how to start right:

<VocabCard
  word="Merhaba, ben [your name]"
  translation="Hello, I am [your name]"
  pronunciation="mer-HAH-bah, ben..."
  example="Merhaba, ben Michael, memnun oldum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sizinle tani≈ütƒ±ƒüima cok memnunum"
  translation="I am very pleased to meet you"
  pronunciation="see-ZEEN-leh tah-nuhsh-tuh-uh-MAH chok mem-noo-NOOM"
  example="Sizinle tanistiƒüima cok memnunum, cok sey duydum sizin hakkinda."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cok sey duydum sizin hakkinizda"
  translation="I have heard so much about you"
  pronunciation="chok shey dooy-DOOM see-ZEEN hahk-kuh-nuhz-DAH"
  example="Cok sey duydum sizin hakkinizda, hep iyi seyler."
/>

<CultureTip title="The Greeting Ritual" flag="üáπüá∑">
Turkish greetings often involve kisses on both cheeks, especially between women and between women and men. With the father, a firm handshake is usually appropriate first meeting. Follow your partner's lead. Elders may offer their hand palm-down for you to kiss the back of - this is a sign of respect you should accept.
</CultureTip>

## Family Member Vocabulary

Knowing what to call family members is essential:

### Parents

<VocabCard
  word="Anne"
  translation="Mother"
  pronunciation="AHN-neh"
  example="Anne, nasilsiniz?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Baba"
  translation="Father"
  pronunciation="BAH-bah"
  example="Baba, tani≈ütƒ±ƒüimiza memnun oldum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kayinvalide"
  translation="Mother-in-law"
  pronunciation="kah-yuhn-vah-lee-DEH"
  example="Kayinvalidem cok tatli bir kadin."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kayinpeder"
  translation="Father-in-law"
  pronunciation="kah-yuhn-peh-DER"
  example="Kayinpederim cok saygi duyulan biri."
/>

### Siblings

<VocabCard
  word="Abla"
  translation="Older sister"
  pronunciation="AHB-lah"
  example="Abla, memnun oldum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Abi"
  translation="Older brother"
  pronunciation="AH-bee"
  example="Abi, nasilsiniz?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Kiz kardes"
  translation="Sister (younger or general)"
  pronunciation="kuhz kahr-DESH"
  example="Kiz kardesin cok tatli."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Erkek kardes"
  translation="Brother (younger or general)"
  pronunciation="er-KEK kahr-DESH"
  example="Erkek kardesinle tanismak isterim."
/>

<CultureTip title="Age-Based Titles" flag="üáπüá∑">
In Turkish, older siblings have special titles: **Abla** for older sister and **Abi** for older brother. You should use these titles when addressing your partner's older siblings - it shows respect. Even after you become close, you will likely keep using these titles. Dropping them would seem disrespectful.
</CultureTip>

### Extended Family

<VocabCard
  word="Buyukanne"
  translation="Grandmother"
  pronunciation="bew-yewk-AHN-neh"
  example="Buyukanne, ellerinizi opebilir miyim?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Buyukbaba"
  translation="Grandfather"
  pronunciation="bew-yewk-BAH-bah"
  example="Buyukbaba, nasilsiniz?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Teyze"
  translation="Aunt (mother's side)"
  pronunciation="tey-ZEH"
  example="Teyze, memnun oldum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Hala"
  translation="Aunt (father's side)"
  pronunciation="hah-LAH"
  example="Hala, sizinle tanistigima cok memnunum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Dayi"
  translation="Uncle (mother's side)"
  pronunciation="dah-YUH"
  example="Dayi, nasilsiniz?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Amca"
  translation="Uncle (father's side)"
  pronunciation="ahm-JAH"
  example="Amca, memnun oldum."
/>

## Essential Polite Phrases

### Formal Respect

Turkish has formal and informal "you." Always use formal **siz** with your partner's family, especially at first:

<VocabCard
  word="Nasilsiniz?"
  translation="How are you? (formal)"
  pronunciation="NAH-suhl-suh-nuhz"
  example="Merhaba, nasilsiniz?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cok tesekkur ederim"
  translation="Thank you very much"
  pronunciation="chok teh-shek-KEWR eh-deh-REEM"
  example="Cok tesekkur ederim, cok naziksiniz."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Rica ederim"
  translation="You're welcome"
  pronunciation="ree-JAH eh-deh-REEM"
  example="Rica ederim, zevkle."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Lutfen"
  translation="Please"
  pronunciation="lewt-FEN"
  example="Evet, lutfen, cok tesekkurler."
/>

<CultureTip title="Sen vs. Siz" flag="üáπüá∑">
Using **siz** (formal you) instead of **sen** (informal you) with elders is crucial. Even after years of knowing them, many Turkish people continue using siz with their in-laws. When in doubt, use siz. They may eventually invite you to use sen, which is an honor and sign of acceptance.
</CultureTip>

### Expressions of Respect

<VocabCard
  word="Elinizi opebilir miyim?"
  translation="May I kiss your hand?"
  pronunciation="el-ee-nee-ZEE oh-peh-bee-LEER mee-YEEM"
  example="Buyukanne, elinizi opebilir miyim?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Size cok saygi duyuyorum"
  translation="I have great respect for you"
  pronunciation="see-ZEH chok say-GUH doo-yoo-YO-room"
  example="Size cok saygi duyuyorum, sizi tanidiƒüim icin mutluyum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Cok naziksiniz"
  translation="You are very kind"
  pronunciation="chok nah-zeek-see-NEEZ"
  example="Cok naziksiniz, tesekkur ederim."
/>

## At Their Home

### When Arriving

<VocabCard
  word="Bunlar sizin icin"
  translation="These are for you"
  pronunciation="boon-LAHR see-ZEEN ee-CHEEN"
  example="Bunlar sizin icin, umarm begenirsiniz."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Eviniz cok guzel"
  translation="Your home is very beautiful"
  pronunciation="ev-ee-NEEZ chok gew-ZEL"
  example="Eviniz cok guzel, cok sicak bir ortam."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Hos bulduk"
  translation="Response to 'welcome'"
  pronunciation="hosh bool-DOOK"
  example="Hos bulduk, tesekkurler."
/>

<CultureTip title="Never Go Empty-Handed" flag="üáπüá∑">
Always bring a gift when visiting a Turkish home. Traditional choices include: chocolates, Turkish delight, pastries (baklava), flowers (avoid roses unless romantic), or something from your home country. Present it saying "Bunlar sizin icin" (These are for you). The host will graciously accept and likely serve it to everyone.
</CultureTip>

### During the Meal

<VocabCard
  word="Cok lezzetli"
  translation="Very delicious"
  pronunciation="chok lez-zet-LEE"
  example="Cok lezzetli, tarifinizi alabilir miyim?"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ellerinize saglik"
  translation="Health to your hands (thank you for cooking)"
  pronunciation="el-leh-ree-nee-ZEH sah-LUHK"
  example="Ellerinize saglik anne, harika olmus."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Doydum, tesekkurler"
  translation="I'm full, thank you"
  pronunciation="doy-DOOM, teh-shek-kewr-LER"
  example="Cok tesekkurler, doydum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bir parca daha alabilir miyim?"
  translation="Could I have another piece?"
  pronunciation="beer pahr-CHA dah-HAH ah-lah-bee-LEER mee-YEEM"
  example="Bu cok lezzetli, bir parca daha alabilir miyim?"
/>

<CultureTip title="Turkish Hospitality and Food" flag="üáπüá∑">
Turkish hosts will insist you eat more - and more, and more. They may physically put food on your plate. Refusing too quickly can seem rude. Accept graciously at first, and when truly full, say "Cok tesekkurler, gercekten doydum" (Thank you so much, I'm really full). Leaving a little food shows you were satisfied. Clearing your plate may signal you want more!
</CultureTip>

### Complimenting Their Home and Cooking

## Answering Common Questions

Turkish parents will have questions. Be prepared:

### About Your Work

<VocabCard
  word="... olarak calisiyorum"
  translation="I work as a ..."
  pronunciation="... oh-lah-RAHK chah-luh-shuh-YO-room"
  example="Muhendis olarak calisiyorum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Isimi cok seviyorum"
  translation="I love my job"
  pronunciation="ee-shee-MEE chok seh-vee-YO-room"
  example="Isimi cok seviyorum, cok tatmin edici."
/>

### About Your Family

<VocabCard
  word="Ailem ... yasyor"
  translation="My family lives in ..."
  pronunciation="ah-ee-LEM ... yah-shuh-YOR"
  example="Ailem Amerika'da yasiyor."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bir kiz kardesim/erkek kardesim var"
  translation="I have a sister/brother"
  pronunciation="beer kuhz kahr-deh-SHEEM/er-KEK kahr-deh-SHEEM vahr"
  example="Bir kiz kardesim ve bir erkek kardesim var."
/>

### About Your Intentions

<VocabCard
  word="Niyetlerim ciddi"
  translation="My intentions are serious"
  pronunciation="nee-yet-leh-REEM jeed-DEE"
  example="Niyetlerim ciddi, ona cok deger veriyorum."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Gelecegimizi birlikte goruyorum"
  translation="I see our future together"
  pronunciation="geh-leh-jeh-ee-mee-ZEE beer-leek-TEH goh-rew-YO-room"
  example="Gelecegimizi birlikte goruyorum, onu cok seviyorum."
/>

<CultureTip title="The Intentions Question" flag="üáπüá∑">
Turkish families may directly ask about your intentions. This is not rude - it is caring. They want to know their child is with someone serious. Being honest and expressing commitment will earn you respect. Phrases like "Niyetlerim ciddi" show you understand the importance of family blessing.
</CultureTip>

## Leaving and Follow-Up

### When Leaving

<VocabCard
  word="Cok tesekkur ederim, harika bir gun gecirdik"
  translation="Thank you so much, we had a wonderful day"
  pronunciation="chok teh-shek-KEWR eh-deh-REEM, hah-ree-KAH beer gewn geh-cheer-DEEK"
  example="Cok tesekkur ederim, harika bir gun gecirdik."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Bizi agirladiginiz icin tesekkurler"
  translation="Thank you for hosting us"
  pronunciation="bee-ZEE ah-uhr-lah-duh-uh-nuhz ee-CHEEN teh-shek-kewr-LER"
  example="Bizi agirladiginiz icin tesekkurler, cok guzel vakit gecirdik."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Sizi tekrar gormek isterim"
  translation="I would like to see you again"
  pronunciation="see-ZEE tek-RAHR gohr-MEK ees-teh-REEM"
  example="Sizi tekrar gormek isterim, lutfen bize de gelin."
/>

### Inviting Them Back

<VocabCard
  word="Sizi bize davet etmek isteriz"
  translation="We would like to invite you to our place"
  pronunciation="see-ZEE bee-ZEH dah-VET et-MEK ees-teh-REEZ"
  example="Sizi bize davet etmek isteriz, haftaya musait misiniz?"

## Quick Reference: Essential Family Phrases

| Situation | Turkish | Pronunciation |
|-----------|---------|---------------|
| Nice to meet you | Memnun oldum | mem-NOON ol-DOOM |
| How are you? (formal) | Nasilsiniz? | NAH-suhl-suh-nuhz |
| Thank you very much | Cok tesekkur ederim | chok teh-shek-KEWR eh-deh-REEM |
| These are for you | Bunlar sizin icin | boon-LAHR see-ZEEN ee-CHEEN |
| Your home is lovely | Eviniz cok guzel | ev-ee-NEEZ chok gew-ZEL |
| Delicious | Cok lezzetli | chok lez-zet-LEE |
| Health to your hands | Ellerinize saglik | el-leh-ree-nee-ZEH sah-LUHK |
| I love your daughter/son | Kizinizi/Oglanizi cok seviyorum | kuh-zuh-nuh-ZUH chok seh-vee-YO-room |

## Tips for Success

1. **Dress conservatively** - First impressions matter; err on the formal side
2. **Remove shoes** - Always take off shoes when entering unless told otherwise
3. **Bring gifts** - Never arrive empty-handed
4. **Accept food** - Graciously accept what is offered; refusing repeatedly is rude
5. **Use formal language** - Always use siz until invited to use sen
6. **Show respect to elders** - Stand when they enter, offer your seat
7. **Praise the cooking** - "Ellerinize saglik" goes a long way
8. **Be patient** - Meals and visits are long; enjoy the process
9. **Follow up** - A thank-you message after shows good manners

<CultureTip title="The Long Game" flag="üáπüá∑">
Building a relationship with Turkish in-laws takes time. They may seem reserved at first, but this is not rejection - they are observing you. Be consistent, respectful, and genuine. Over time, you will become family in the truest sense. Once a Turkish family accepts you, their loyalty and love are deep and lasting.
</CultureTip>
